author: Mynamejeff66666
body:
Futures will healthily decline throughout the night with people taking profits, allowing new entry points, etc. to stay about -2% nothing to worry about or crazy. 

Meanwhile, Jerome Powell’s alarm clock sounds at 0430. Wakes up, takes a deep breath and realizes he has to live another day as himself. Despair creeps in, but he distracts himself by pulling up his investing.com app he heard all the kids are using. “-2%? Huh. Donny will kill me.” He thinks. He brews a pot of coffee and studies some transcendental meditation techniques for a couple hours. -2.5% now. “I tried, i tried. But the natural course is not the right one” he muttered.  He dials the phone, “Yeah....yeah....you know what to do. Print.” His motorola razr clicks has he shuts it. In the distance, he hears the cries of a bear in the distance, so close, but ever so far away. “Oh look, my eggs are ready.” Jerome scrapes the eggs off the pan, and tries to savor them before he gets a call from Donald thanking him for doing his job. He hated him. But what choice did he have? Suicide? No, fuck, push those thoughts away. “Just eat your eggs J, just eat your eggs....” he implores himself

author: Bellamy88
body:
For me the 3 companies I regret not investing in was Microsoft, Monster Energy and ethereum (not exactly a company I know).

 

Microsoft:

In 2005 I discovered the stock market for the first time at 16 and I wanted to invest but back then I thought investing was super risky, basically gambling like playing slots... Anyway I had £500 that I had got from my family for getting certain grades at school and after looking at a list of companies I decided I was going to invest in Microsoft only to discover that I wasn't old enough to open an account.

A year later and by the time I was old enough I had completely forgotten all about it and had blown the money on clothes, a swanky new Motorola Razr and other assorted material goods.

 

Monster Energy:

Then I got my first job in 2007 after finishing my A-Levels and by late 2008 I had a few thousand in savings. The housing crash had really started kicking in and everyone was terrified the world was ending so I had about £2000 in savings but was terrified to invest in the stock market. Nevertheless my curiosity made me look into what things were looking like and again I was looking at a bunch of companies and remember looking back at Microsoft thinking "wow I'm so glad I didn't invest in Microsoft back in 2005 " as it was currently down about 30% from when I was going to invest in 2005.

As a huge Monster Energy drinker back then, that was one of the companies I looked at and had it not been for the huge crash, I probably would have bought in just because I enjoyed the beverage...

 

Ethereum:

The next 8 years or so it never occurred to me to think about investing again and so I just spent money like it was going out of fashion until I quit my job and decided to look for a new career. I decided upon programming (never stuck with it) and somehow I remember stumbling onto bitcoin on a programming forum. I first heard about bitcoin back when it was selling for a dollar but I literally thought it was some scammy game currency people were selling like runscape gold so I didn't do any research into it at all.

Anyways I decided to check the price and my mind was blown... $250 bitcoin, like what the fuck! Of course this got me very interest until I heard about Mt Gox and it was crashing so thought the scam was over. I came into contact with Ethereum, which at the time had just ICO'd and was about $2 but I was still sceptical, if bitcoin was a scam, then surely the thing copying bitcoin is a scam... right?

I was uneducated at the time and didn't know much about any of this stuff. I watched ethereum on and off and watched it "crash" from $2 to $0.40 and was very smug that I didn't fall for the scam... Again I had forgotten about it completely until a few years later and long story short, I fomo'd into ethereum at $250 in 2017 after doing a lot of research, I rode the wave all the way up to $1400, didn't take any profit, ended up selling at $250 in 2018... It took me 12 years to pluck up the courage to invest in something since first discovering investing and it was a damn cryptocurrency 🥴

 

But if I did invest in Microsoft, Monster and Ethereum and held my positions, to this day I'd have:

Micorsoft: £500 @ ~$25 = £3,200 (560%)

Monster Energy: £2000 @ ~$4 = £30,600 (1404%)

Ethereum: (probably would have only invested £100 or so) @ $2 = £7613 (7513%).

 

So what stories do you have?

author: onfallen
body:
tesla isn't any of those companies. The possibility of it becoming the next Apple, however slim, justifies its market cap. Other car companies are like Nokia and motorola during the rise of apple.

imagine tesla licensing its technologies to ALL other car companies, offering subscription packages to customers. A default spot on its car infotainment may be worth billions alone. It may or may not do these things, but they are fully capable. Tesla's driving data alone is worth at least tens of billions of dollars alone. Its market share in electric cars means , combined with ai powered improvements, means that no car company may ever catch up again, maybe except google, but google don't make cars yet (google ever getting deeply involved in car business would surely slam tesla to the ground, for a while)

Tesla is not a car manufacturer. Its market cap is greater than all those companies combined because it has discovered and innovated revenue streams that none of those companies have imagined possible,and none of them could copy.

author: lnsufficientgravitas
body:
It's very simple - VWAP is simply the volume weighted average price.  Go look at your favorite ticker and add VWAP + an upper and lower band set to a factor of 2.  Look back over time at how the stonk tends to trade around VWAP and the upper/lower bands.

Most of the time, you should see that the stock will want to "float" back to VWAP throughout the day-sometimes it doesn't, but it's better than just trying to trace a chart with your finger on robinhood and guestimate purely off price and not volume.

Combine this with time and sales flow to get an idea as to the momentum.  It's something you need to just play with and get a feel for.

My approach is basically - has the stock plunged well below VWAP, and pierced the lower bound?  I probably wouldn't go short but will consider going long to catch a bounce back to VWAP.  Inverse?  Consider going the other way.  Sitting at VWAP and VWAP is flat?  Probably won't touch it as I'm not an oracle  


It's not a silver bullet though and won't always work - I've seen SPY explode over VWAP and just keep reaching upwards, beyond the upper band.  I've tried to short from here and have gotten stopped out as JPOW's raging erections just keep blowing out the chart with green dildos.

author: SomethingMusic
body:
[cisco has diminishing cash on hand](https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/CSCO/cisco/cash-on-hand), though they probably can handle operating expenses for 3 months on savings

[Oracle has also significantly](https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/ORCL/oracle/cash-on-hand) reduced cash

Still, the point being most businesses do not have the liquidity necessary to operate for a significant time without income, especially small and medium-sized businesses who have to operate against bigger businesses on thinner margins. 60% of US population is living paycheck to paycheck, [and only 10% businesses have enough savings to operate for two months, and 20% of businesses can operate for 2m with decreased revenue](https://twitter.com/LizAnnSonders/status/1247619174039465988). 

Small business has seen the biggest decline in 34 years, and you cannot based your decisions on the few cash rich businesses that are successful.

author: CrimsonBrit
body:
I appreciate the thought and effort that went into this write-up, however, you've done quite a bit of due diligence to ultimately pick 80% of the **FAANG** stocks (Facebook ($FB), Amazon ($AMZN), Apple ($AAPL), Netflix ($NFLX); and Alphabet ($GOOG) with Netflix being the one you did not pick in your list of six companies.

Each of the FAANG stocks trades on the Nasdaq exchange and is included in the S&P 500 Index. Since the S&P 500 is a broad representation of the market, where the FAANGs make up about 15% of the S&P 500—a staggering figure considering the S&P 500 is generally viewed as a proxy for the United States economy as a whole,  you have basically just invested in the market as a whole, as stated by /u/Chuckox50.

Not to mention that investing in Berkshire ($BRK.A) is like investing in an index fund of sorts, where Berkshire's "fund" also owns positions in Apple (33.9%), Amazon (0.57%), and Johnson & Johnson (0.24%), adding to your positions in those three companies. Additionally, Berkshire owns relatively small positions in the SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust ([$SPY](https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/SPY:US)) and VANGUARD IX FUN/S&P 500 ETF SHS NEW ([$VOO](https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/VOO:US)) ETFs, which both track the S&P 500 and in turn have positions in some of the companies you have mentioned: Microsoft ($MSFT), Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Berkshire, Johnson & Johnson, and Alphabet.

**That being said, I still think that they are rock-solid choices and I have several of those on my radar and just as many already in my portfolio, and I intend to add to my positions for those companies.**

I am investing for the long-term and currently have a high tolerance for risk, so the majority of the stocks on my lengthy list of about 55 companies on my radar right now are tech.

Just to mention a bunch of them (on top of MSFT, AAPL, GOOG, NFLX, FB, and AMZN):

* Financial: Visa, Mastercard, PayPal, Square
* Healthcare: JNJ, UnitedHealth, AbbVie, Illumina, InVitae
* Services: AMZN, Walmart, Disney, Spotfiy
* Technology (Software): Oracle, Adobe, Salesforce, Shopify, Splunk, Docusign, Twiliio, The Trade Desk
* Technology (Gaming): Activision Blizzard, Take-Two
* Technology (Semiconductors): Intel, NVIDIA, AMD, Micron, Teradyne
* Telecom/Communications: Verizon, AT&T, Cisco

I would like to caution you for your analysis in the write-up in regards to Berkshire. You state that your rationale for Berkshire having a competitive edge post-COVID-19 is simply "Warren Buffett". By the time that COVID is on the decline, Buffett will be 90 years old. I think the company can thrive without him, but if your basis for investing in that company for the long-term is a man born in 1930, I think you need to reassess your rationale.

Go with individual stocks if you enjoy stock picking, you can index in your 401k and ESOP.

- add AYX and possibly ANET to your tech list, everything else on there looks great.
- I like higher growth names in healthcare as well, LVGO, GH, HQY come to mind as all long term plays (I also own Illumina, watching NVTA but don’t love it)
- PINS and SFIX seem to have a lot of upside from current levels as well, (SFIX popped pop my radar due to incredible amounts of insider buying). 

Hope this gives you some decent ideas, either approach seems well thought out and would work fine.  I guess it depends on how much time you want to dedicate to it and how much you enjoy stock picking.

author: InvestPalaver
body: Some companies are serial acquirers they make acquisitions every year and they state that it is part of their growth strategy. For example ORCL will be making acquisitons every year. So I treat it similar to how you would forecast Capex. Usually capex is taken as a % of revenue historically then projected forward, I do the same with acquisitions. They do tend to be lumpier so my model will be smoother than the eventual reality but what you are trying to get to is how much capital the company is reinvesting in the business. I also want to make sure that my growth projections are not out of line with my reinvestment requirements so sometimes I will use acquisitions to fill that gap.

author: rainTendies
body:
Perfect example of how important it is to not over-leverage on positions especially if having short-term timelines. Recognize "theta gang"/option writers are most effective at making profits selling options =< 45 days DTE and they do well. As an options holder/buyer one has to be able to "go long" and be strict with following risk and money mgmt and understand how to pick tickers/contracts having the "greeks" with best potential and avoiding those with the worst potential. Similar as it is in the world of investing in mutual funds/ETFs in a 401k/IRA (diversify and avoid pricey managed load-fee funds) there is such a thing as diversifying in options trades (not all-in on SPY or SPY and QQQ, place only small % on a position, include a contrarian position, don't overpay, always keep sufficient "dry powder"/cash equity that allows for repositioning in trades you believe in but market moved against in near term, have plan when to enter/exit before making a trade, don't get emotional, cut losses sooner rather than later, etc).  

You know you're in trouble if this applies:  

\--> If you catch yourself using the word “hope”. You’re fucked. “ I hope it goes up” “ I hope it goes down”. Your hopes will get crushed. <--

SV/VS never gave instructions. He gave his interpretation of what the market appears to be doing and where it may be heading and provided his positions. He clearly included the not financial advice caveat. NO ONE CAN PREDICT THE MARKET. With this one we are in unprecedented times. When you hear of hedge funds and experienced trading firms blowing up their accounts, it would be unbelievable if some internet stranger was a Guru/Oracle who could predict the market moves with timing that is only off by days and ticker price moves only off by 5 pts or less. The reason he got such a huge following was because his earliest posts seem to do just that and as time moved forward it became clear to everyone that no one can predict and not even the most detailed thorough TA can give away clues for what will happen a week+ down the road.  

Have a fun ride on this rollercoaster of a market! Of course I'm holding Poots that are very depressed/down at the moment. =)

author: pkincy
body: Frankly I forget.  It was in the Human Resources software busines.  Not Oracle, not PeopleSoft, not Tom Seibel but a very similar company.  I had executive clients at all of these companies but only had one prospective client at the company I am talking about.   He was an executive and had 100% of his networth in the company.   Right before the first discovery of the books being cooked we had recommended he take $10 mm of his company stock and do a Charitable Remainder Trust.  I forgot exactly what his lifetime income would have been....like half a million a year.  He declined and so he lost about $70 mm when the stock tanked.   They moved the hdqtrs to Colorado from Silicon Valley and somehow clawed their way back to profitability and a high stock price.  The second time I met with the client we recommended a $5 mm CRT again to lock in some diversification and life time income as well as generate some tax deduction so he could sell some of his low basis company stock.  Again he declined.  The second time he lost nearly all of what was that time about $60 mm of stock.  Brilliant people don't always make the best decisions.

author: gizamo
body: Every big tech company has Sr devs making that much, or even much more. Here's a [2012 break down of pay for devs at GOOG](https://www.infoworld.com/article/3304439/man-or-myth-the-3-million-google-engineer.html), but AAPL, FB, NFLX, CRM, etc. all pay many devs that much. That said, I'm not at a tech company. So, it's not unheard of outside of tech as well. I even know guys at IBM and ORCL who make that much, and those guys are known to pay their devs poorly.

author: PepeSilviaFTW
body:
The more I look at AAPL, the more I think *"When is the last time they did something truly great?"* The market has always been about what have you done for me lately. 

Apple is consumer brand. A $400 phone is at the bottom of most peoples priority list right now. I see them being traded at around $200 in 2-3 months.   
MSFT has enterprise level solutions that will solve most remote office hurdles.   
They will continue to rise.   
I'm about to go for a run, but I could go on about IBM, Oracle, and the tech sector all day.   
DPZ, DG, NFLX, etc. are being rewarded for the convenience of there current offerings.   


Just thinking out loud about how some companies will be traded in the next few weeks, months, years.    


What are some of y'alls thoughts?

I've never heard of Ponos Industries but after googling the name, it looks like they're basically just trolling big corporations offering to buy shares at huge discounts or premiums. They did the same thing with AT&T and Oracle last year

Edit: found the scam

https://www.investors.com/promoted-content/ponos-industries/notice-of-offer-to-purchase-for-cash-up-to-500000-shares-of-common-stock-of-the-boeing-company-at-180-00-net-per-share-by-ponos-industries-llc/

> ...however, the Offer is conditioned upon the satisfaction or waiver (where applicable) of a number of conditions set forth in the Offer to Purchase, including, among other things, the closing price of the Shares on the New York Stock Exchange on the last full trading day prior to the Expiration Date exceeding the Offer Price...

"We'll only buy them from you at $180 if the share price is over $180 at the expiration of the offer"

author: xblackout_
body:
I'm very familiar with the space, the simple way to find out if smart contract technology makes sense with a particular use case is to ask 'do you trust the other party'? If the answer is no, then perfect, that's the problem that smart contracts solve. Trustless transactions.

Personally I'm bullish on: Ethereum, Chainlink, IOTA, Bitcoin.

BTC: I see this as being an eternal legacy store of value. Highly illiquid, should be treated as digital gold. The hedge of the space.

Eth: Most promising and popular platform for innovation, moving to proof-of-stake meaning improvements to efficiency and it's got a better 'at scale' thanks to the addition of layer 2 development on top.

Chainlink: 'The' Oracle network. This requires a bit of technical knowledge to understand, but this network works in conjunction with other types of DLTs. It solves the biggest problem of smart contract technology. Essentially it lets DLT applications make API calls to external systems (the web). I'm most bullish on this by far.

IOTA: an outlier, a potential game changer. A more exploratory type of network that uses DAG tech which could ultimately be the fastest and cheapest per transaction. The team has made great progress and this tech has the potential to disrupt the rest, but their scope of work and vision is massive.

author: TrollFarm4
body:
You keep dodging the question.

> One example is in supply chains/inventory management. Companies have ERP accounting systems from decades ago that are essentially information silos not only within their own company, but also to other organizations/companies/partners that they are working with.

Blockchains do not replace ERP systems, they are just a data structure that could be used by parts of an ERP system for something like a supply chain.

So let's start there, I want to upgrade the ERP system for my company. Can you quantify why I should use a blockchain over oracle or workday?



> Instead of employing (and trusting) tons of people to inefficiently manage these systems, isn’t it cheaper/easier/better to have all necessary information available on an as needed basis to all network participants

You've got it backwards. Blockchains are inefficient because they focus on being trustless. Centralized systems are incredibly efficient. 

The reality is that it's significantly easier and cheaper to just not use a blockchain. There's a reason why next to no one actually uses blockchains.

author: ss_400401
body:
Most state projects are developed in Microsoft .net and that has been from a long time.  Bought calls based on the following factors starting with the recent NBA deal and would advice you buy calls expiring in August or Sep since you will have time to hedge if anything goes sideways next week.

 [https://www.cnbc.com/amp/2020/04/16/microsoft-and-nba-sign-azure-surface-deal-starting-in-2020-21-season.html](https://www.cnbc.com/amp/2020/04/16/microsoft-and-nba-sign-azure-surface-deal-starting-in-2020-21-season.html)

1. Microsoft Teams  will eat slacks lunch and the new office 365 cloud subscription model which started on 4/21 has teams included. I believe corporations will slowly dump slack because of the higher costs and join Teams. Unfortunately it cannot take on zoom as zoom is a superior video conferencing tool.
2. JEDI contract will help secure future government contracts and helps further to move the legacy applications from Cobol or whatever language the state's are running to .Net/ C#
3. Has Visual studio, .net ( asp.net, c# and vb.net) to compete against java. Also SQL server competes directly with Oracle DB
4. New Xbox releasing this year
5. Linked helps during hard times like this
6. GIT Hub - 60% of the worlds open source software projects are stored on GIT hub
7. Azure which is the crown jewel and competes with AWS
8. VR/ AR with Hololens and hardware with surface
9. I assume they will buy Service now or Sales force since Microsoft Dynamics is not that of a great CRM tool.
10. If azure can prove its reliable for NBA, it will open doors for international games like Soccer, Formula1, Olympics etc..

author: JDragon1
body:
U/Spuri0n have you taken a look at the competitors? IBM (Kenexa), Oracle, Citrix, and SAP released their 2019 annual reports. Some of them released their Q1 earnings, too.

Oracle and IBM earn 70-80% of their revenue from their cloud based services and software. SAP and Citrix (Web-Ex) is more weighted in this area. Growth has been trailing for all of these companies, except for one: Citrix.

My favorite out of all of them, including Cornerstone, has to be Citrix. Unfortunately, that Citrix ship has sailed. It had a damn check mark recovery! Citrix seems like a safe bet to go long, but this LMS industry seems like a short term play for me. 

I'd stick with CSDO for the earnings play with a small position of $32.5 5/15 calls. I would prefer going out to June, but there is no volume.

I think I'll wait and see how Citrix behaves to decide if I want to jump in long term.

author: Sarkham89
body:
? 

I mean I suppose it depends on how you define a lot.

Consumer staples, almost all,  entirely benefit from this. The majority of the tech stocks will benefit from this. Grocery retailers, biotech. 

I’m not sure if you are thinking big enough. Maybe you think every restaurant, airline, and consumer discretionary is struggling and NFLX will benefit. Here let me rattle of a list of large companies for you and you can check out there peers that are in the industry. 

Off the dome:

KHC, ORCL, NFLX, INTC, AMD, CAG, STZ, ZM, ATVI, CLX, KR, NVDA, PEP, KO, COST, GILAD, SPOT, CHWY, AMZN, MSFT, CISCO, RNG, SPOT, EVERYBIOTECHINDUSTRY, EVERYECOMMERCESERVICE, EVERYINTERNETSECURITY, EVERYSTREAMINGSERVICE, EVERYCLOUDBASED

Those are just some tickers, there are probably thousands more tickets that all BENEFIT or remain very largely unaffected from the Coronavirus. As a majority I’m certain that most businesses will service. 

I know since I’ve been unemployed I’ve subscribed to three online subscriptions and have bought at least a half dozen books. 

Did anyone use Zoom before Coronavirus? 

So, depends how you define a lot, I suppose. Important to note, it is not majority, tho.
